issues.text: Whether grant of preference to Perumal Padayatchi on the ground of place of birth (being native of Pondicherry) violates Article 15 of the Constitution

anchor.surface_text: The main contention urged on behalf of the petitioner is that the order of the appellate Authority shows that preference was granted to Perumal Padayatchi on the ground that he was a native of Pondicherry  i. e. he was born in Pondicherry , while the petitioner was merely a resident of Pondicherry  i. e. he was born in Pondicherry . The petitioner contends that such grant of preference on the ground of place of birth is hit by Art. 15 of the Constitution as the petitioner

issues.text: Whether the petitioner has a right to apply for special leave under Article 136 against an order passed by a tribunal in Pondicherry when it was not within the territory of India

anchor.surface_text: no right to apply to this Court for special leave under Art. 136 of the Constitution nor would the petitioner would have no right to proceed by way of a writ petition under Art. 32 against an order which was passed by the Appellate Authority in Pondicherry at a time when Pondicherry was not in the territory of India.

issues.text: Whether the Appellate Authority is a 'local or other authority under the control of the Government of India' within Article 12 such that writ under Article 32 can issue against its order passed outside the territory of India

anchor.surface_text: Turning now to the writ petition, the main question that falls for consideration is the effect of Art. 12 and whether on a proper interpretation of that Article, the Appellate Authority could in this case be said to be a local or other authority under the control of the Government of India.

issues.text: Whether in Article 12, the phrase 'under the control of the Government of India' qualifies 'territory of India' or 'local or other authorities'

anchor.surface_text: we have therefore to examine the contentions of either party as to the exact scope and effect of the words all local or other authorities within the territory of India or under the control of the Government of India, as if the question is res integra. The first contention on behalf of the petitioner is that the words under the control

issues.text: Whether 'under the control of the Government of India' in Article 12 means control by appointment, payment and discipline, or requires control over functions

anchor.surface_text: Further,, there can be no doubt that if no writ could issue to the Appellate Authority at the time the order was passed, no writ could issue now after Pondicherry has become part of the territory of India, for that would be giving retrospective operation to the Constitution for this purpose which obviously cannot be done

issues.text: Whether a quasi-judicial authority outside the territory of India but under administration of Government of India is 'under the control of the Government of India' per Article 12

anchor.surface_text: The next question is whether a judicial or quasijudicial authority outside the territory of India but within the territory under the administration of the Government of India can be said to be under the control of the Government of India. For this purpose we have to find out the meaning of the words under the control of the Government of India as used in Art. 12.

issues.text: Whether writ jurisdiction under Article 32 applies retrospectively to orders passed before Pondicherry became part of India

anchor.surface_text: Further,, there can be no doubt that if no writ could issue to the Appellate Authority at the time the order was passed, no writ could issue now after Pondicherry has become part of the territory of India, for that would be giving retrospective operation to the Constitution

issues.text: Whether a writ in the nature of certiorari can issue to quash a quasi-judicial order passed by an authority outside the territory of India

anchor.surface_text: whether a writ in the nature of certiorari or other appropriate order or direction to quash a quasi- judicial order passed by an authority outside the territory of India, though such authority is under the control of the Government of India could issue.

arguments.claim: Appeal not maintainable under Art. 136 as order passed by tribunal outside territory of India

anchor.surface_text: Admittedly, Pondicherry was not within the territory of India when the order was passed and therefore Art. 136 would not apply to such an order. We have already indicated that this position is conceded on behalf of the petitioner.

arguments.claim: Quasi-judicial authority cannot be under 'control of GOI' per Art. 12 as GOI cannot control its functions (rule of law)

anchor.surface_text: in the very nature of things, where rule of law prevails, it is not open to the Government, be it the Government of India or the Government of a State, to direct a quasi-judicial or judicial authority to decide a particular matter before it in a particular manner.

arguments.claim: No writ jurisdiction under Art. 32 retrospectively for pre-integration orders

anchor.surface_text: Further, there can be no doubt that if no writ could issue to the Appellate Authority at the time the order was passed, no writ could issue now after Pondicherry has become part of the territory of India, for that would be giving retrospective operation to the Constitution for this purpose which obviously cannot be done

arguments.claim: Discrimination by quasi-judicial authority not by 'State' under Art. 12, so no breach of Art. 15

anchor.surface_text: Art. 15 prohibits the State from discriminating against any citizen on grounds only of religion, race, caste, sex, place of birth or any of them. Therefore it is only when the State as defined in Art. 12 ... discriminates, that a citizen can complain of the breach of Art. 15

holdings.text: Article 136 of the Constitution does not apply to an order passed by a tribunal when Pondicherry was not within the territory of India.

anchor.surface_text: Admittedly, Pondicherry was number within the territory of India when the order was passed and therefore Art. 136 would number apply to such an order.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Pondicherry admittedly outside territory at time of order; position conceded by petitioner; appeal concluded by Masthan Sahib case.

holdings.text: In Article 12, the words 'under the control of the Government of India' qualify 'all local or other authorities' and not 'within the territory of India'.

anchor.surface_text: On the other hand, the contention on behalf of the respondents is that the words under the control of the Government of India qualify the word authorities and not the word territory in the relevant part of Art. 12 and that that part on its true interpretation would read thus all local or other authorities within the territory of India or all local or other authorities under the control of the Government of India.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Grammatical structure and scheme of Article 12 indicate two kinds of authorities: those within territory and those under GOI control wherever located.

holdings.text: 'Under the control of the Government of India' in Article 12 means control over the functions of the authority, not merely appointment, payment, or disciplinary control.

anchor.surface_text: It follows from these observations in the majority decision in that case that the control envisaged by the words under the control of the Government of India in Art. 12 is not the control which arises out of mere appointment, payment and the right to take disciplinary action the control envisaged under Art. 12 is a control of the functions of the authorities concerned,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Control must enable GOI to direct functions; mere administrative control insufficient as implied in Masthan Sahib.

holdings.text: A quasi-judicial authority outside the territory of India but administered by GOI is not 'under the control of the Government of India' within Article 12 due to lack of functional control and rule of law.

anchor.surface_text: Such control is possible in the case of a purely executive or administrative authority it is impossible in the case of a quasi-judicial or judicial authority, for in the very nature of things, where rule of law prevails, it is not open to the Government, be it the Government of India or the Government of a State, to direct a quasi-judicial or judicial authority to decide a particular matter before it in a particular manner.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rule of law precludes GOI directing quasi-judicial decisions; follows implication from Masthan Sahib where writ not issued against such authority.

holdings.text: No writ under Article 32 can issue against a quasi-judicial order passed by an authority outside the territory of India, even if under GOI administration.

anchor.surface_text: If the order of the authority under the control of the Government of India but functioning outside the territory of India was of an executive or administrative nature, relief could be afforded to a petitioner under Art. 32 by passing suitable orders against the Government of India directing them to give effect to the decision of this Court by the exercise of their powers of control over the authority outside the territory of India.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct enforcement impossible; indirect via GOI ineffective for quasi-judicial orders per Masthan Sahib.

holdings.text: Constitutional jurisdiction under Article 32 does not operate retrospectively to validate writ against pre-existing orders after territory integration.

anchor.surface_text: Further,, there can be no doubt that if no writ could issue to the Appellate Authority at the time the order was passed, no writ could issue now after Pondicherry has become part of the territory of India, for that would be giving retrospective operation to the Constitution for this purpose which obviously cannot be done

holdings.reasoning_summary: No retrospective operation to Constitution; cites Janardan Reddy v. State.

holdings.text: Article 15 does not apply to discrimination by a quasi-judicial authority not constituting 'State' under Article 12.

anchor.surface_text: Art. 15 prohibits the State from discriminating against any citizen on grounds only of religion, race, caste, sex, place of birth or any of them. Therefore it is only when the State as defined in Art. 12 ... discriminates, that a citizen can complain of the breach of Art. 15

holdings.reasoning_summary: Art. 15 protects only against State discrimination; Appellate Authority not State as quasi-judicial without functional control.

edges.explanation: Fact order passed when Pondicherry outside India triggers issue of retrospective Art. 32 jurisdiction post-integration.
The petitioner's filing of the writ petition against the order triggers the issue of whether such a writ of certiorari can issue.
Holding h1 supports and affirms concept c3 by restating that Art. 136 does not apply to such tribunal orders outside territory.
Holding h1 directly addresses and negates the issue i2 of whether there is a right to special leave under Art. 136 for Pondicherry order when not in territory.

anchor.surface_text: Admittedly, Pondicherry was number within the territory of India when the order was passed and therefore Art. 136 would number apply to such an order.
We therefore dismiss the appeal and pass numberorder as to companyts in respect thereof. We dismiss the writ petition with companyts.

On the other hand, the contention on behalf of the respondents is that the words under the control of the Government of India qualify the word authorities and not the word territory in the relevant part of Art. 12 and that that part on its true interpretation would read thus all local or other authorities within the territory of India or all local or other authorities under the control of the Government of India.
We therefore dismiss the appeal and pass numberorder as to companyts in respect thereof. We dismiss the writ petition with companyts.

anchor.surface_text: Such control is possible in the case of a purely executive or administrative authority it is impossible in the case of a quasi-judicial or judicial authority, for in the very nature of things, where rule of law prevails, it is not open to the Government, be it the Government of India or the Government of a State, to direct a quasi-judicial or judicial authority to decide a particular matter before it in a particular manner.
We therefore dismiss the appeal and pass numberorder as to companyts in respect thereof. We dismiss the writ petition with companyts.

anchor.surface_text: If the order of the authority under the control of the Government of India but functioning outside the territory of India was of an executive or administrative nature, relief could be afforded to a petitioner under Art. 32 by passing suitable orders against the Government of India directing them to give effect to the decision of this Court by the exercise of their powers of control over the authority outside the territory of India.
We therefore dismiss the appeal and pass numberorder as to companyts in respect thereof. We dismiss the writ petition with companyts.

anchor.surface_text: Further,, there can be no doubt that if no writ could issue to the Appellate Authority at the time the order was passed, no writ could issue now after Pondicherry has become part of the territory of India, for that would be giving retrospective operation to the Constitution for this purpose which obviously cannot be done
We therefore dismiss the appeal and pass numberorder as to companyts in respect thereof. We dismiss the writ petition with companyts.

edges.explanation: The holding constrains the Fundamental Rights concept (Article 15) by limiting its applicability to entities constituting 'State' under Article 12.
The holding states that Article 15 does not apply to discrimination by a quasi-judicial authority not constituting 'State', directly addressing the issue of violation of Article 15.

anchor.surface_text: Art. 15 prohibits the State from discriminating against any citizen on grounds only of religion, race, caste, sex, place of birth or any of them. Therefore it is only when the State as defined in Art. 12 ... discriminates, that a citizen can complain of the breach of Art. 15
We therefore dismiss the appeal and pass numberorder as to companyts in respect thereof. We dismiss the writ petition with companyts.

edges.explanation: The issue directly concerns whether a preference violates Article 15 of the Constitution, which falls under the Fundamental Rights concept.
